title: Concerning the "i was defending myself" argument

replies.body:
Good quote. 
I also notice none of them "defend themselves" calmly. They're never saying "I played the situation the best I knew how" or "there wasn't much I could do", it's always rising to match the bait.

Never is such a strong word.  More than a few times I "defended" myself by "If I go in, I will just die to them 2v4" or "I'm not chasing into a dark unwarded jungle with you when all of them are mia" followed swiftly by full mute of the person and possibly a report.

> [{quoted}](name=zPOOPz,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=MeExcEpV,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2018-10-19T11:47:30.784+0000)

And if you get reported for that, you won't get punished, because you weren't doing anything wrong.
it was in refference to the people who can't control themselves. not you

Or anyone getting offended and being emotional about it, the kind Rito tries to protect. 

Stepped on your own tail, huh?

everyone who gets offended and becomes emotional is usually banned for toxicity because there's only one type of emotion that happens: rage

so i don't know what you mean

I mean that people do not necessarily display that emotion in chat, they just mute and report people, but your post applies to them.

It's basically "grow a thicker skin", which is often said by punished players in their posts.

> [{quoted}](name=SonicAF,realm=EUW,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=MeExcEpV,comment-id=000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-10-19T13:22:00.819+0000)

"Grow a thicker skin" is what people say TO the punished players. Because they are usually talking about how they "stood up for themselves" or some bullshit that actually translates to: I have thin skin so i blow up when people say anything critical of me.
Or they say that the community should grow a thicker skin and chat-related bans should become a history.

> [{quoted}](name=SonicAF,realm=EUW,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=MeExcEpV,comment-id=00000000000000000000000000010000,timestamp=2018-10-19T23:41:17.374+0000)
>
> Or they say that the community should grow a thicker skin and chat-related bans should become a history.

Yeah they say that like how a cnn host i forget the name of, calls Ben Shapiro a bully when he goes on his show. It's a classic attempt to deflect. You be the bully, call the other person a bully first to control the narrative. It just comes down to personal opinion I guess... But my personal opinion is that those who are toxic tend to be the thinner skinned, more insecure individuals. Meh. Not saying you're wrong, though. There is no objective right or wrong here probably. (Especially since we are just generalizing)

It's not a matter of comparing though. It doesn't matter who is more insecure - the one who tells the losing laner to kill himself, the one who responds to that or the one who gets offended and silently reports either of them. All of them are, and "you will continue to suffer if you have an emotional reaction to everything that is said to you".

The only thing that makes me guessing is if Riot's policies form community perception of what is acceptable or if this perception is just a slice of western society.

If it's the latter, Riot is somewhat justified in creating their hegemonic punishment system, but in the former case they are **the** bully. They are a huge abuser. And they are getting away with it because it's written in ToS - "we are always right, even if proven wrong". I find it unacceptable.

Sadly, taking a real slice of western society to prove any of that stuff is difficult. Let everyone in without any rules and limitations and you end up with something resembling 4chan - and not everybody can handle 4chan, let alone participate in their community.
Yeah I know, I can't believe how ironic this post is. Rules only apply when it fits their narrative I guess .

I wouldn't exactly say rage is the only emotion you feel during that time...you need more than just raw anger to get yourself to an emotional breakdown... Despair, sadness, but also anger and hatred towards the ones who offend you and you offend them back because you are hurt, stabbed. Or how everyone says it sarcastically, "defend yourself". Of course it isn't deffending yourself, it's simply an eye for an eye and the world goes blind...fighting fire with fire and down this world goes to ashes. I've been there, and I do agree with the origin post that such provokations are passive and shouldn't bother paying attention to people you'll see only once in your game and prolly never again. But do you have any idea, how it feels like to he one of THEM? They might be as toxic as everyone else in your eyes, but they are also sad and scarred, just like anyone who is aware that their actions have big consequences to pay, or people who are so mich covered in their arrogance they can't see what's coming to them.
As for emotionally unstable people...to them taking words into their heart is like getting emotionally backstabbed to death, not having the will not to say anything is like not having a shield...a shield that is tilt proof against the words of the likes of those jerks who have nothing better to do but bait THOSE type of emotional people into getting penalized. For them being the fish who took their bait.
I get it that you'll say anything to prove me wrong, and everyone else too, wnd it's fine, opinions matter and differ. All I wanted to say is that I know how it feels like to be them because I WAS in fact one of them, remember?
{{sticker:cass-cry}}

What? So its bullshit to expect your kid to make his own way? Wtf???? Are you young? You must be quite young.

I think having any amount of wealth, and leaving absolutely none of it to your child/children is a generally very rude and asshole-ish thing to do. When you live in a capitalistic society like ours that places a monetary value on literally every aspect of life; including things required to live, any amount of wealth could mean a massive difference in lifestyle. For some like myself, an excess of money is required to stay alive.

And when you have a net worth of 10 million dollars like Bruce Lee happened to have, leaving not a cent of it to your children is not only a massive gesture of what (I assume) is ill-will, it's just overall incompetence. That money could have been used for any number of positive things not just for his son, but for others as well.

I think at some point you have to abandon the sentiment of "good old-fashioned family values" and realize the world that you're in. I hold nothing against the man otherwise and agree with the quote.

Children born into wealth have a 400% greater chance of dying by the age of 30. They dont have responsibility, they dont have the hunger to achieve because they dont need to achieve anything. They often end up with major drug addictions because of their lack of responsibility. But to each their own. I dont think you should judge him based on his decision to do that. You dont know the right way anymore than anyone else. Its incredibly arrogant to refer to a man as "that dumbass who..." based on them not just giving their children money. Others would agree, others would disagree... so to think that you know best is just arrogance. Im not saying he should have or should not have, because I dont know what is best. You dont either.

The irony with your username has me rolling with this one. I feel kinda torn on this issue as I do understand where the parents are coming from. They want their kids to not be spoiled on their success, and would rather teach them how to survive and hustle for themselves. I think the middle ground is to tell your kids you're not leaving anything for them so they learn how to work and the value of money, but to actually give them something when you actually go. 

But I think as a parent if you're loaded, and you really leave absolutely nothing for your kids, especially if they are actually hustling, and not expecting a large payout from you at the end you're doing it wrong. Its a weird paradoxical thing isn't it?

can I ask where you see the irony in my name? I was a bit brash in my first comment, but I feel as though I haven't been completely rude or belligerent with my argument. 

you're right in that the issue is quite multi-faceted. In this scenario; I have to assume Mr. Lee didn't die when his child was extremely young (like 10 and under) meaning that his child grew up around a large amount of wealth already.  Telephone Booth (the guy who responded to me before) makes a good point in saying that children born into an excess of wealth tend to be lacking in the department of personal responsibility, because of the warping effect massive amounts of cash tend to have. And to be clear; I think it would be a very stupid move for Mr. Lee to leave his entire 10 million dollar fortune to his son's hands, regardless of his age.

But he didn't leave all of it. In fact, he didn't leave any of it. I don't know where the money actually went to be honest; but I think with that kind of excess wealth leaving none of it to your child is a bit of a shit move. I ALSO have to assume that because his son grew up around a lot of money, he's in a decent place in his life financially, anyways. 

I guess my anger comes from a place of assuming the money went to nobody. That much money can do A LOT of good. In the end you'd think he would've chipped a bit off to at least give his son a good start; but, like i said, his son was probably in a stable place financially anyways. 

Leaving nothing to anybody is just... irresponsible. Did he do that? No clue.
